rComments: zzzzzzzzzzzzzzz. Seriously...not just because it was an 8am class. She posts the slides after class. Goes along with the textbook mostly. She might be passionate about her work but she didn't light the fire in me. Go to class + pay attention to her announcements + do the light amount of homework = A+
Much more interesting than Phono 1, but more demanding. Lots of homework, like any other upper division Ling class. Do the work, go to section, don't fall asleep in class.

Well, I liked Junko Ito as a person, she's very nice, and she knows what she's talking about, but she's a bit dull as a teacher. Lectures are very repetitive and roundabout, with great lenght of time devoted to very tiny details. Because of details, I lost my interest in the overall concern, and I don't see the point in Optimality Theory anymore.

The key to doing well in Junko's class is to take notes.  The problems in the homework will be variations on those discussed in class.   The write-ups need to be in comprehensive essay format.  Not that difficult really. If it still doesn't click, Junko is accessible and generous with her time.  A classy lady, and a good experienced professor.

I took phonology with Junko with only the intro class under my belt.  The class was terribly difficult with only this prerequisite.  Junko, as a lecturer, is rather boring.  She explains subject matter very in-depth and knows the material.  However, her explanations are rather difficult and roundabout at times.  One-on-one, she is so much better.
I had Junko for Phono 1, and it was SO hard.  She jumped right into the fray on the first day, and I almost cried.  My previous ling classes didn't help at all, and I withdrew.  Get help early!

Doesn't lecture on relevant material till after homeworks are due. Assignment prompts are unclear (didn't specify the guidelines for the final paper until the last minute). Office hours are useless... But look on the bright side! She knows what she's talking about and in general, her lectures are clear, she just can't teach. Try for another prof.

Not great. Had her for Phono 1. The format she'd like for the hw is frustratingly unclear. Will find yourself wondering how you should write your rules/derivations/lexicon, w/o any clear guideline explicating how to execute that exactly. Unfortunately, she's also a fan of repetitive processes. Must write up UR of every form + morphemes in every hw
Junko is soooo funny and a great teacher however her lectures can be a bit on the sleepy side, especially when taking her at night....but a great and amazing prof and person :)

Junko is the frickin' bomb and I don't use the word 'frick' lightly.  Seriously though, she's one of the best professors I've had at UCSC. I highly recommend her class if you are into Japanese and Linguistics. I would, however, advise some background in the language before considering this class, otherwise it would probably be much more difficult.

Junko is a fabulous teacher and a truly kind person, but I would not recommend taking Structure of Japanese without a background in the language (which may seem obvious but I didn't think it would matter since it's not a prereq).
